title: Turkish troops attack in Syria as US denies giving ‘green light’ to move in
text:
Turkey has launched a major offensive in northern Syria, moving thousands of troops across the border after pounding suspected Kurdish-held areas with air strikes (Pictures: Reuters/IHA)

Turkey’s soldiers crossed the border into Syria to battle Kurdish fighters hours after Turkish warplanes pounded areas in the north of the country.

Thousands of Turkish troops have been joined by allied Syrian opposition forces for the offensive, Turkey’s defence ministry said.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced the airstrikes and ground attack on Twitter on Wednesday afternoon, naming it ‘Operation Peace Spring’.

It came after President Donald Trump agreed to withdraw American troops from northern Syria, paving the way for an assault on forces that have long been allied with the US.

Mustafa Bali, a spokesman for the US-backed Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, said Turkish warplanes were targeting ‘civilian areas’, causing ‘a huge panic’ in the region.

US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has this morning said the US did not give Turkey a ‘green light’ to begin its attack on northern Syria.

Mr Pompeo defended President Trump’s decision to withdraw US troops from the border area, which has sparked an outcry at home and abroad.

Smoke rises in the civilian city of Ras al-Ayn, near to the Turkish border in Syria as Operation Peace Spring gets underway (Picture: Getty)

Turkish President Erdogan says the offensive in Syria is to protect his country from the ‘threat of terror’ (Picture: IHA)

Turkey has said its assault on territory held by Kurdish-led forces aims to eradicate ‘the threat of terror’ to its country.

President Erdogan said he wanted to prevent ‘the creation of a terror corridor’ on the border with his country.

Turkish forces plan to make a ‘safe zone’ cleared of Kurdish militias which will house Syrian refugees.

But Kurdish-led forces – who helped the US defeat Islamic State (Isis) in Syria – vowed to resist the offensive and have already clashed with Turkish troops.

The Kurds guard thousands of Isis fighters and their relatives in prisons and camps in areas under their control.

Advertisement

Advertisement

It is unclear whether they will continue to do so if battles break out.

US President Donald Trump called the strikes on Kurdish fighters in Syria – who helped the US defeat Isis – a ‘bad idea’ (Picture: Getty)

The Kurds guard thousands of Isis fighters and their relatives in prisons and camps in areas under their control but it is unclear whether they will continue to do so if battles break out (Picture: AFP)

Turkey says it’s troops are being supported by the Syrian National Army (Picture: EPA)

One of the towns under attack from Turkish forces, Ras al-Ayn, is a residential area where civilians live.

Panic began on the streets of the town as airstrikes broke out, with cars racing to safety.

It was not clear if they were leaving the town or heading away from the Syrian border where the conflict has broken out.

Near the town of Qamishli, plumes of smoke were seen rising from an area close to the border after activists reported sounds of an explosion nearby.

The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights put the death toll at eight, including two Christian Assyrians in the city of Qamishli, a husband and wife and their child as well as another man in a village outside of the town of Tal Abyad, and a child in a village west of Qamishli.

Also killed was a man in Ras al-Ayn, it said.

The Observatory said at least seven fighters from the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces were killed in the fighting.

Advertisement

The Kurdish forces have warned of a ‘humanitarian catastrophe’ that could potentially unfold because of the Turkish military operation.

Mr Erdogan said in a tweet: ‘Our mission is to prevent the creation of a terror corridor across our southern border and to bring peace to the area.’

His ‘Peace Spring’ operation involves Turkish Armed Forces fighting alongside Turkish-backed Syrian fighters known as the Syrian National Army, the president said.

Turkey’s President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced the offensive on Twitter (Picture: EPA)

A spokesman for the US-backed Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces said Turkish warplanes were targeting ‘civilian areas’ (Picture: AFP)

Turkish jets began pounding suspected areas held by Syrian Kurdish forces in Ras al-Ayn before Mr Erdogan’s announcement, activists said.

The sound of explosions could be heard in Turkey, with activists saying it was difficult to know what was hit in the first hours of the operation.

It is feared Turkey’s attack will ignite new fighting in Syria’s eight-year-old war, potentially displacing hundreds of thousands of people.

Mr Trump has threatened to ‘totally destroy and obliterate’ Turkey’s economy if the Turkish offensive in Syria ‘went too far’.

Yesterday he said the US does not endorse the assault on northern Syria and has made it clear to Ankara that its incursion against Kurdish fighters who helped the US fight so-called Isis is a ‘bad idea’.

He face criticism for abandoning an American ally in his decision to withdraw US troops from the area.

Mr Trump argue he does not want the US to fight ‘these endless, senseless wars’.

Advertisement

United Nations diplomats say the UN Security Council will hold a closed meeting today to discuss Turkey’s military action.

The UK, along with France, Germany, Belgium and Poland, requested the meeting on Wednesday, the diplomats said.
